Posts.Content: I am 4 days post-op now and agree with everything Michael F listed. I've been using neosporin but I do have to clean the tube and reapply a few times a day. I had bought some cargo pants a size bigger and I actually swelled up the first 2 days post-op and couldn't use them, ( I think I went from a 34" waist up to about 38" - swelling has went down quite a bit in the last 12hrs.) . I had a baggy pair of sweatpants that worked. I cut a vertical slit on the left thigh and have the tube come out there. I also just use the large bag. I live in the country so I just have a shoulder strap off a duffle bag hooked to the string on the large bag. I don't think my Amish neighbors will mind seeing me walk around with it. I used the leg bag to come home from the hospital and will use it Wednesday to go get the tube removed. I use a strap in the shower to hook the bag onto also when showering.

Posts.Content: Good deal on the anniversary! That's a great thing about this forum is to hear updates about what's possibly down the road. (PDV, thanks for the info about "phantom" squirts. I'm 13 days post-op and had some dribbles the first few days. The last 3 days a couple times a day it felt like it but nothing. I thought I was nuts.) I hope I can put a post on here in a year with great news also. Congratulations

Posts.Title: One year anniversary....

Posts.Content: I think incontinence is different with everybody. I'm 19 days post Da Vinci. The first few days after the catheter was removed I had "drips and dribbles". The next few days I was dry and thought I had it made. I am used to exercising and figured I could at least go for a fast walk for a couple miles. Then I climbed up a ladder to drill a couple holes and put some hooks in a post. That's when the fun began. I became fully incontinent and blood was mixed in my urine. Also my testicles were pulling up and down and twisting around by themselves. After 2 hours of this I called my surgeon. He has a cellphone for patients to call and he answered on a Saturday afternoon! He said to drink a lot of water to flush the blood out and to be there Monday morning if the other stuff was still happening. He said " Didn't someone tell you to take it easy?". An hour later I was dry, no blood in the urine, and my testicles quit squirming. I've been completely dry since, not even any "phantom" drips like I was having before. I don't know if I had twisted a nerve or what, I'll ask him about it when I see him in a couple weeks. So my 2 cents worth is to take it easy, (was told it can take 8 weeks for tissue to heal up in there), and only drink fluids when you're thirsty to give the bladder and urethra time to heal, (unless you're trying to flush blood out of your urine). Good Luck Rooster.
Posts.Signature: Born 1959, Father diagnosed-w-PC in his 70's My PSA"S June 2012- 1.25, Oct 2013- 6.20 (switched family doc & wanted a PSA), Nov 2013- 3.65, Mar 2014- 3.69, Apr 2014- Biopsy( 1 of 16 cores High Grade Pin Cells, Rest normal ), Oct 2014- 3.85, Mar 2015- 3.57, Mar 2016- 4.33, April 21, 2016- Biopsy( 2 of 14 cores 3+3, 5% and 20% ), June 14, 2016- Prolaris Score on Biopsy Sample 4.4, Jul 28, 2016- DaVinci Prostatectomy at Age 56 ------ Catheter Removed Aug 3, 2016, Pathology: 2 Bilateral Tumors, Gleason 7 (3+4) on Both, Negative Margins.
Posts.Title: Incontitent discussion w/MD

Posts.Content: Ask your doctor for a copy of your genomic test and have him explain it. These tests have proven highly accurate at showing the cancer's aggressiveness. I had the Prolaris test. It scores different than your test but when the results came back my surgeon took active surveillance off the option list. I am almost a month postop and am happy with my choice because he got it before it got out of the prostate. Everybody is different with prostate cancer and the treatment side effects but try to get in the best physical shape you can beforehand. Like others have said, radiation targeting is a lot better now. My father had brachytherapy in the late 90's and passed from colon cancer in 2010. The radiation was brought up as a possible cause but no one knows for sure. That and my age is why I chose surgery. Good luck, I know making "the choice" is the hardest part of all this.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs Beams vs Seeds vs Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Thank you for the welcome. The Prolaris Score can go from -3 to 7. Negative numbers are less aggressive. When I met the surgeon to find out my score I asked him first if I had a minus 3. That's when he looked over his glasses and said it's 4.4 and he'd only seen a number that high a couple other times. These genomic tests have only been out for a little over three years. I don't want to sound like an expert on these things. It's hard to find info that's not just on Myriad's website, (the owner of Prolaris). I have found reviews on medical journal websites that say the Prolaris Score is very accurate concerning outcomes. My 10 year mortality rate was 30%. The Prolaris Score is supposed to be an accurate predictor of biochemical recurrence also. I asked my surgeon about this and he said he wants to get it out and that everybody is different when it comes to prostate cancer. As for him saying it was a perfect surgery he told my wife that means no problems or surprises. He told her he thinks it was still contained but will know more from the pathology report. I get the catheter out next Wednesday. I don't know if the pathology report will be in then. I just wanted to put my experience out here since there is not a lot of info on actual results compared to a high Prolaris Score and if catching it early made a difference.
Posts.Signature: Born 1959, Father diagnosed-w-PC in his 70's My PSA"S June 2012- 1.25, Oct 2013- 6.20 (switched family doc & wanted a PSA), Nov 2013- 3.65, Mar 2014- 3.69, Apr 2014- Biopsy( 1 of 16 cores High Grade Pin Cells, Rest normal ), Oct 2014- 3.85, Mar 2015- 3.57, Mar 2016- 4.33, April 21, 2016- Biopsy( 2 of 14 cores 3+3, 5% and 20% ), June 14, 2016- Prolaris Score on Biopsy Sample 4.4, Jul 28, 2016- DaVinci Prostatectomy at Age 56 ------ Catheter Removed Aug 3, 2016, Pathology: 2 Bilateral Tumors, Gleason 7 (3+4) on Both, Negative Margins.
Posts.Title: Prolaris Score 4.4

Posts.Content: Had my catheter removed yesterday. That makes everything a little bit easier. Pathology on surgery showed 2 bilateral tumors with a gleason score of 7, (3+4), on each one. The biopsy 3 months earlier showed 1 tumor with 2 positive cores beside each other with a gleason score of 6, (3+3). Negative margins, negative on lymph nodes, both nerve bundles saved. The surgeon said "You're essentially cured". I asked him about the high Prolaris score and he said what counted with that was getting the prostate out before the cancer got outside the prostate. I get a PSA test and see him in 4 weeks. With that news I forgot all about getting a copy of the complete pathology report. I'll get that next time. They just put basic information on their patient portal. When I came back out to the receptionist counter I saw my wife through the window in the waiting room and gave her "thumbs up" and she started crying. I had mentioned before that I didn't need any pain meds before. That was until I wasn't thinking 3 days post-op and got in bed like normal and pulled on my abdomen. I took one that night and another the next morning.

Posts.Title: Prolaris Score 4.4

Posts.Content: Hello, you have listed "perineural invasion" on your signature. I don't think active surveillance would be an option. That means it's along a nerve in the prostate. Unfortunately that is a quick route out of the prostate and you don't want that to happen. I had a genomic test done on my biopsy sample that switched my surgeon and I from active surveillance to surgery. It measures the aggressiveness of the cancer. The Prolaris Test is what I had but I don't know if they can do it on just a 5% positive sample. (The list price on the test is high but my insurance has a negotiated price of about $150 of which I paid 20%). Good luck and you've found an excellent forum for support and info on PC.

Posts.Title: Need to decide - what would you do and why did you choose it?

Posts.Content: I've been reading this forum for the last month and greatly appreciate all the tips and advice. I had my robotic surgery yesterday. I thought I would put something on here because my surgery was done mainly because of a Prolaris Score of 4.4. My surgeon has done over 800 robotic surgeries. He has been using a genomic test to measure the aggressiveness of the biopsy sample. He said he has only seen a score this high a couple other times. Talked to a radiologist also and went with the surgery. Before the Prolaris Score came back my surgeon was thinking active surveillance. When he saw the score he didn't want to waste any time. I'll keep posting about this because I could find very little about people with Prolaris Tests done. Surgery was 3 hours and he said it was a perfect surgery. I haven't had to take any pain meds. Since this is my first post I don't know if my history from my profile automatically shows up. Thanks again to everybody on here for making this a lot easier.
